official-title.#text:
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to prevent foreign diplomats from being eligible to
			 receive health insurance premium tax credits and health insurance
			 cost-sharing reductions, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: No Healthcare Subsidies for Foreign Diplomats Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: No Healthcare Subsidies for Foreign Diplomats Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The Congress finds the following:
The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(in this section referred to as
			 the “Affordable Care Act”) established certain taxpayer-funded subsidies,
			 such as premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions, that directly or
			 indirectly pay portions of the costs of health insurance and services for
			 eligible individuals and households.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
staff members who are not citizens or lawful
			 permanent residents of the United States do not pay Federal income taxes
			 on their salaries from those employers.

text.#text: Diplomats of foreign governments and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has notified foreign missions in the United States, permanent missions to
			 the

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Department of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
employees in the United States are
			 currently eligible to obtain United States taxpayer-funded subsidies under
			 the

, such as premium tax credits and cost-sharing
			 reductions, on the same basis as American citizens and lawful permanent
			 residents.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

text.#text: According to the

United States diplomats overseas do not depend on foreign taxpayers for health care coverage, but
			 rely on United States-based health insurance plans that provide overseas
			 coverage.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
does not currently collect data that would allow it to
			 identify any foreign diplomats who are enrolled in a qualified health plan
			 and who may be receiving premium tax credits or cost-sharing reductions
			 pursuant to the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Department of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
also does not possess that data, and has asserted that it is not involved
			 in whatever processes foreign diplomats may use to obtain benefits funded
			 by the United States Government.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
does not collect visa information and is not currently able to discern
			 whether any taxpayer is present in the United States pursuant to an A
			 (diplomatic) or a G (UN/international organization) nonimmigrant visa.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
also does not collect data identifying whether a foreign diplomat is
			 enrolled in a qualified health plan and is receiving a premium tax credit
			 or cost-sharing reduction pursuant to the Affordable Care Act.

text.#text: The
It is the sense of Congress that—

foreign diplomats should be allowed to purchase health insurance coverage in the United States, but
			 the cost of that coverage should be borne by their sending States; and
United States taxpayers should not subsidize the health insurance expenses of foreign diplomats.

header.#text:
Foreign diplomats ineligible to receive health insurance premium tax credits and health insurance
			 cost-sharing reductions
For health insurance premium tax credits

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

text.#text: by redesignating subsection (g) as subsection (h); and
by inserting after subsection (f) the following new subsection:

header.#text: Denial of credit to foreign diplomats

text.#text:
No credit shall be allowed under this section to any individual for any month during any portion of
			 which such individual is a foreign diplomat.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 101(a)(15)(G) of the Immigration and Nationality Act

term.#tail: means an alien admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant under

text.#text: For denial of cost sharing reductions to individuals ineligible for the premium tax credit under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 1402(f)(2)
			 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act/s:1402/ss:f/p:2

text.#text:
The amendment made by paragraph (1) shall apply to foreign diplomats for months beginning more than
			 30 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, in taxable years
			 ending after such date, regardless of whether the diplomat may have been
			 determined eligible for a premium tax credit or cost-sharing reduction (or
			 advance payment with respect to such credit or reduction) before such date
			 of enactment.
